description: Inherited from Middle English swage, from Old French souage (“decorative groove”), from soue (“rope”), from Vulgar Latin *soca, from Gaulish *souca (“cord”), from Proto-Celtic *soukā, from Proto-Indo-European *sew- (“to twist, bend”).

entries.meaning: A tool, used by blacksmiths and other metalworkers, for shaping of a metal item.

verbs.description: swage (third-person singular simple present swages, present participle swaging, simple past and past participle swaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bend or shape through use of a swage.

verbs.description: swage (third-person singular simple present swages, present participle swaging, simple past and past participle swaged)
